meeting_annotations.transcript: Now that we've we've wrapped this up, there's no need to take notes now, Hannah. Because But um have you guys ever looked at you know like um plants or a tree dispersal? And you know, you look at a tree like a um um oak. I don't I don't know trees. Um and then most of those oaks when there's a mass year, they fall right around that that's a curve, right? So most of the oak acorns are falling right around the base of the tree. And then there's one of those acorns that gets grabbed by a little squirrel and then dashes off and that seeds that next big oak tree that forms the forest. So how can we capture that dynamic with our pathogens and pandemics? Do we just apply plant dispersal curves to pandemics or do we come up with a different framework theoretically and think about it that way? I don't know. The rare events with long distance dispersal.
